body.p:
To His Excellency
Thomas E. Bramlette
Governor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner John Welch would respectfully state that he was Tried at the may term of the Jefferson Circuit Court upon an Indictment for the murder of Allen Gavin. A verdict of guilty was rendered & he was sentenced to be hanged July 22d 1864.

The true facts of the killing are as follows, On the morning of the unfortunate killing Petitioner was at the house of deceased & was attacked by the husband of decd with an axe, & in shooting at the Husband unfortuantely his wife was killed.

Your Excellency is respectfully refered to a certified copy of the evidence had on the Trial & also a statement of the abandon character of the
witnesses for the commonwealth, your petitioner is a private Soldier, in the 130th Reg Ind Vol, enlisted in Dec 1863.
Your petitioner never intended any harm to decd & now feels an unestemable sorrow that the sad accident caused the death of Mrs Gavin,
Your Petitioner prays your Excellency to grant him a pardon
We the undersigned citizens of Louisville Kentucky earnestly unite in the prayre of the Petitioner

understanding that a majority of the Jury which tried the case have joined in a petition for the pardon, I, therefore, unite in the prayer in like manner.

Respectfully
Robt J. Elliott
ass't city attorney

I see that seven nine of the Jurymen that tried the petitioner have asked for his pardon, Nearly all of those, who have signed the petition, are well known and are well acquainted with the circumstances attending the killing of Mrs Gavin, and are well acquainted with the witnesses for the prosecution, on the trial, and their statements are entitled to full credit and influence

Respectfully
W G Reasor cty att.
